title: Hoosier Oscars: And the winner is ...
text:
Hoosier Oscars: And the winner is ... Will Higgins , will.higgins@indystar.com Published 12:00 p.m. ET Feb. 19, 2015 | Updated 59 minutes ago “Close Encounters of the Third Kind,” where an ordinary Joe from Indiana sees a UFO and is forever changed, prevailed in the Hoosier Classics division. (Photo: Provided by Columbia Pictures) 590 CONNECT 9 COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Dozens of movies have been filmed in Indiana, and dozens more tell stories that take place in Indiana. 
We figured it was time to proclaim one of them the "Best Indiana-centric Picture Ever." 
We nominated 25 films, in six categories. We presented the list to an expert panel of our choosing. Its 13 members, locals all, selected winners in each category and, ultimately, an overall Best Indiana-centric Picture Ever. 
The nominees: 
Division I: Hoosier Classics 
"Breaking Away" (1979) — Story about pretension and class-based meanness set in Bloomington, where locals, derided as "cutters" (Dennis Christopher, Dennis Quaid, Daniel Stern) rise up and compete with college kids — and beat those jerks. 
"Close Encounters of the Third Kind" (1977) — Typical, average Hoosier from Muncie (Richard Dreyfuss) sees a UFO; his odyssey commences. 
"Going All the Way" (1997) — Coming-of-age/buddy story of cool guy Gunner (Ben Affleck) and geek Sonny (Jeremy Davies); probably the Hoosierest movie ever because: A) the story was written by an Indianapolis-born novelist who is one of our panelists, Dan Wakefield; B) the action takes place in Indianapolis; C) the movie was filmed in Indiana. 
"The Magnificent Ambersons" (1942) — Story of a rich, genteel Indianapolis family that gets crushed by the industrial revolution; story based on the novel by Indianapolis writer Booth Tarkington. 
And the winner is "Close Encounters of the Third Kind." 
"Humankind has yet to concede to the possibility of intelligence in the universe that is superior to our own," said panelist Alpha Blackburn, an interior designer, fashion designer and painter, and a director of Heartland Film. "This is a saga of enduring intrigue and intellectual curiosity." 
Division II: Sports 
"A League of Their Own" (1992) — Pro women's baseball team (with Geena Davis and Madonna, among others, and Tom Hanks as their coach) competes with heart; filmed extensively in Indiana: Evansville, New Harmony, Huntingburg, St. Phillips. 
"Eight Men Out" (1987) — Chicago baseball players including ones played by John Cusack and Charlie Sheen agree to throw the 1919 World Series; filmed partly at Indianapolis' old Bush Stadium on 16th Street. 
"Madison" (2005) — Tale of big-time hydroplane racing on the Ohio River at Madison, where the underdogs, the Hoosiers, in an outdated boat, win; filmed in Madison; written and directed by Indianapolis-born brothers Bill and Scott Bindley. 
"Hoosiers" (1986) — A little Indiana town rises up and is counted by winning the state high school basketball championship. 
And the winner is "Hoosiers." 
"No other sports film has the cross-generational appeal or climactic endorphin rush as this 1986 masterpiece," said panelist Stuart Lowry, president of Heartland Film. 
(Photo: Provided by Orion Pictures) 
Division III: Biopics 
"Public Enemies" (2009) — John Dillinger, the Indianapolis-born bank robber (Johnny Depp), takes money that isn't his, seduces a woman, gets away from the cops over and over. Until he doesn't. 
"De-Lovely" (2004) — The complex life of the songwriter Cole Porter (Kevin Kline), born in Peru, Ind. 
"Kinsey" (2004) — Sex research pioneer Alfred Kinsey, who taught at Indiana University in the mid-20th century, is brought to life by Liam Neeson. 
"The Story of G.I. Joe" (1945) — The World War II dispatches of newspaper columnist and Dana, Ind., native Ernie Pyle (Burgess Meredith) are made into a cohesive story; film released weeks after Pyle's death, in battle, during the invasion of Okinawa. 
And the winner is a tie between "Public Enemies" and "Kinsey." 
"Johnny Depp (as Dillinger) delivers some of the greatest lines since 'Casablanca,"' said panelist Wakefield. "When the FBI guy asks, 'What keeps you up at night?' Johnny says, 'Black coffee.'" 
"Fascinating," panelist Pauline Moffat, executive director of IndyFringe Festival, said of "Kinsey." "Who knew Alfred Kinsey and his students were getting up to such antics in Bloomington, Indiana." 
(Photo: Provided by Twentieth Century Fox) 
Division IV: Tearjerkers 
"Brian's Song" (1971) — Biracial buddy story involving Chicago Bears football players Gale Sayers (Billy Dee Williams) and Brian Piccolo in which Piccolo (James Caan) dies of cancer; some scenes shot in Rensselaer, Ind. 
"The Ryan White Story" (1989) — A 13-year-old boy from Kokomo is diagnosed with AIDS, bravely faces discrimination and fear; he dies. 
"The Fault in Our Stars" (2014) — Hoosier novelist John Green's story about two Indianapolis teenagers who fall in love. Both have cancer; one dies. 
"Rudy" (1993) — A young man (Sean Astin) grows up idolizing Notre Dame football. He overcomes great odds to actually make the team. The crowd roars. 
And the winner is "Rudy." 
"I have seen it more times than I can count ... but I still blubber like a baby," said panelist Elise Lockwood, promotions and marketing manager at IndyFringe. "I generally don't understand, don't care about football." 
(Photo: Provided by TriStar Pictures) 
Division V: Movies set in Fictional Indiana Towns 
"The Judge" (2014) — A father (Robert Duvall) and son (Robert Downey Jr.), both members of the legal profession, get reacquainted in their hometown of "Carlinville"; there's a hit-and-run; then a trial. 
"A Christmas Story" (1983) — Ralphie, a 9-year-old resident of "Hohman," wants a Red Ryder air rifle for Christmas, gets it. Among other developments. 
"A History of Violence" (2005) — Crime thriller set in "Millbrook," where the owner of a restaurant (Viggo Mortensen) kills two robbers. 
"In & Out" (1997) — Gay high school teacher (Kevin Kline) is outed, loses his job, but then enjoys widespread support from the residents of "Greenleaf." 
And the winner is "A Christmas Story." 
"I haven't pronounced fragile correctly or passed a plate of mashed potatoes without wanting to bury my face in it since the first time I saw 'A Christmas Story,'" said panelist Erin Newell Schneider, director of Film Indiana. "I layer up in my winter gear and whine, 'I can't put my arms down.'" 
(Photo: Provided by Turner Broadcasting) 
Division VI: Films with Crazy Massive Star Power 
"Some Came Running" (1958) — WW II vet (Frank Sinatra) wreaks havoc on his bourgeois brother and on Shirley MacLaine, while riverboat gambler-type guy (Dean Martin) looks on; filmed in Madison, Ind. 
"To Please a Lady" (1950) — A daring race driver (Clark Gable) gets roughed up by a journalist (Barbara Stanwyck) and later roughs her up. Romance ensues; filmed partly at Indianapolis Motor Speedway 
"Rain Man" (1989) — A younger brother (Tom Cruise) tries to take advantage of an older brother (Dustin Hoffman); filmed partly in Franklin County. 
"Winning" (1969) — Race driver A (Paul Newman) loses wife (Joanne Woodward) to race driver B (Robert Wagner); wife's son (Richard Thomas) intervenes; filmed partly at Indianapolis Motor Speedway. 
"Original Gangstas" (1996) — Middle-aged gangsters, who've turned community-minded (Fred Williamson, Jim Brown, Richard Roundtree and Ron O'Neal, with an assist from Pam Grier), return to their hometown and dispense with a young crew of brutal thugs; movie is filmed in Gary. 
And the winner is "Rain Man." 
"The performance by Dustin Hoffman alone makes (Rain Man) one of the best movies of all time," said panelist Scott Stulen, artist and a curator at the Indianapolis Museum of Art. Buy Photo 
(Photo: Frank H. Fisse / The Star) 
Best Indiana-Centric Picture Ever 
"Hoosiers" 
"Amazing, timeless ... the film is Indiana at its pure core," said panelist Craig Mince, executive director of Indy Film Fest and manager of the Indiana State Museum's IMAX Theater. 
Contact Star reporter Will Higgins at (317) 444-6043. Follow him on Twitter @WillRHiggins. 
Our panel of experts 
Alpha Blackburn, an interior designer, fashion designer, painter and a director of Heartland Film. 
Kate Chaplin, writer and director of films and books and host of "Kate's Take" on the D20crit Network. 
Ben Clement, executive director Gary Office of Film & Television and a screenwriter and actor, too. 
Eric Grayson, film historian and preservationist. 
Christopher Lloyd, co-founder of The Film Yap, has been writing about movies for two decades and has won numerous journalism awards for his commentary, which is distributed widely in publications, on websites and on TV. 
Elise Lockwood, promotions and marketing manager at IndyFringe. 
Stuart Lowry, president of Heartland Film. 
Craig Mince, executive director of Indy Film Fest and manager of the Indiana State Museum's IMAX Theater. 
Pauline Moffat, executive director of IndyFringe Festival. 
Kassim Norris, film director, colorist, and composer. 
Erin Newell Schneider, director of Film Indiana, part of the Indiana Economic Development Corp. 
Scott Stulen, artist and curator of audience experiences and performance at the Indianapolis Museum of Art. 
Dan Wakefield, Indianapolis-born novelist who has had two of his books made into movies. One he likes ("Going All the Way"); the other he loathes ("Starting Over"). 590 CONNECT 9 COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://indy.st/1Et1iGg TOP VIDEOS
